conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves downward.
Four objects on a wooden surface: a white sundae cup, a small black object, a white spherical object, and a white cylindrical object with a vertical black element.
Each object casts a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D on the surface.
When a light source moves downward, the angle between the light source and objects becomes steeper.
Shadows move inward, closer to directly beneath their objects.
Shadow A will move closer to being directly beneath the sundae cup.
Shadow B will move closer to being directly beneath the black object.
Shadow C will move closer to being directly beneath the sphere.
Shadow D will move closer to being directly beneath the cylindrical object.
When a light source moves downward, the shadow size decreases as the light source gets closer.
Shadows will become sharper (more defined edges) as the light source moves closer.
Position changes: All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move inward, closer to being directly beneath their respective objects.
Size changes: All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become smaller as the light source moves closer to the objects.
A lower light source creates a steeper angle of incident light, causing shadows to be cast at positions closer to directly beneath the objects.
A lower light source reduces the area over which the shadow is projected.
